questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents with fever, myalgia and cough persisting for the past three days. The cough is non-productive and accompanied by mild nasal congestion. The child has a past medical history of eczema. She had a similar episode a year before and was treated with ibuprofen. Her mother has a known allergy to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). What is the reason this patient will be advised against taking aspirin?
questions.explanation:
Condition

Why Contraindicated?

NSAID allergy

Cross-reactivity can cause severe allergic reactions

Asthma

Risk of bronchospasm due to NSAID-induced leukotriene shift

Children with viral illness

Risk of Reye syndrome

Gout

Aspirin impairs uric acid excretion, worsening gout

Chronic liver disease

Can worsen hepatic injury, especially in high doses

Peptic ulcer/Gastritis

Inhibits prostaglandins → increased GI bleed risk

Bleeding disorders

Inhibits platelet aggregation → ↑ risk of bleeding

questions.text: Match the following drugs with their mechanism of action. a. Colchicine 1. Xanthine oxidase enzyme inhibitor b. Pegloticase 2. Microtubule inhibitor c. Febuxostat 3. Increase uric acid excretion by blocking the OATP cotransporter d. Lesinurad 4. Uric acid is converted to allantoin
questions.explanation:
Colchicine

Microtubule inhibitor

Pegloticase

Uric acid is converted to allantoin

Febuxostat

Xanthine oxidase enzyme inhibitor

Lesinurad

Increase uric acid excretion by blocking the OATP cotransporter

DOC- NSAIDS (All types)

  • Except aspirin and paracetamol
  • Anti-inflammatory

Colchicine (spindle poison)
  • MOA: microtubule inhibitor
  • Used in acute attack of gout, Familial Mediterranean fever and is also the DOC for karyotyping

Corticosteroids
  • Intra articular injections, avoid oral route
  • Immunosuppressive and anti-inflammatory

Xanthine oxidase inhibitors
  • Drugs include Allopurinol (DOC), Oxipurinol, Febuxostat
  • MOA: Blocks xanthine oxidase enzyme → Inhibits the conversion of hypoxanthine to uric acid in liver

Uric acid oxidase enzyme
  • Drugs include Pegloticase and Rasburicase
  • MOA: Uric acid is converted to allantoin and excreted in urine

Uricosuric agents
  • Drugs include Probenecid, Benzbromaron, Sulfinpyrazone, Lesinurad
  • MOA: Inhibit OATP transporter/URAT-1 in kidney → inhibits reabsorption of uric acid → increased excretion of uric acid.
 

(OATP - Organic anion transport protein, URAT-1 - Uric acid transporter)

questions.text: Match the following Biologicals with their respective MOA. BIOLOGICALS MOA a) Rituximab i) Anti-TNFα b) Anakinra ii) Anti-IL6 c) Infliximab iii) Anti-IL1 d) Tocilizumab iv) CD20
questions.explanation:
Mechanism of Action (MOA)

Biological Drug

TNF-alpha inhibitor
  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab

IL-6 receptor antagonist
  • Tocilizumab
  • Sarilumab

CD20-directed cytolytic monoclonal antibody
  • Rituximab

CTLA-4 Ig fusion protein
  • Abatacept

IL-1 receptor antagonist
  • Anakinra

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient with a known case of rheumatoid arthritis for 5 years presents to the clinic with complaints of nausea, fatigue, mouth ulcers and an unusual rash on her legs. She has been on a stable regimen of DMARDs for the past few years. Laboratory investigations reveal a decreased Hb level, elevated liver enzymes, and mild leukopenia. Which drug is most likely responsible for her current symptoms?

A 45-year-old female has been experiencing pain and stiffness in her wrists despite initial treatments. Her rheumatologist decides to start her on disease-modifying therapy (DMARDs). Which of the following statements incorrectly describes the mechanisms of action of the DMARDs? Methotrexate inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, reducing the production of DNA and RNA. Hydroxychloroquine inhibits T-cell activation and reduces the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines. Sulfasalazine is metabolised to 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA), which reduces inflammation of joints in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) Leflunomide inhibits the synthesis of purines, leading to a reduction in lymphocyte proliferation. Infliximab is an oral DMARD that acts by inhibiting interleukin-6.
questions.explanation:
DMARD’s

No.

Medication

Mechanism of Action

1.

Methotrexate (1) (anchor drug)

Inhibition of cytokine production, chemotaxis and cell mediated immune reaction.

2.

Hydroxychloroquine

Block lymphocyte proliferation like chloroquine but with longer action.

3.

Sulfasalazine

The sulfapyridine component blocks lymphocyte proliferation.

4.

Leflunomide

Inhibits DHOLD (Dihydro orotate dehydrogenase) and thymidylate synthase.

5.

Infliximab (I/V)

Certolizumab

Adalimumab

Golimumab

Etanercept

Anti-TNF𝛼

6.

Chloroquine

Inhibits IL1, IL6 TNF-Alpha in lymphocytes, reducing T cell activation.

7.

Tocilizumab

Sarilumab

Anti-IL-6

8.

Rituximab

Anti-CD-20

9.

Anakinra

Anti-IL-1

10.

Abatacept

Recombinant CTLA4, inhibits CD80/86

11.

Tofacitinib

Janus kinase (JAK) inhibitors

12.

Penicillamine

Gold (Au)

Azathioprine

Inhibits macrophage and decreases IL-1

13.

Azathioprine

Cleaved to 6-mercaptopurine (6MP) and inhibit purine synthesis

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presented to the hospital with early morning stiffness in her joints for the last few weeks. She reports severe pain in her right wrist and left knee. Increased CRP levels are seen in laboratory testing. What is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Treatment of Rheumatoid Arthritis

Acute arthritis

 
  1. Mild-moderate
 
  • DOC: NSAIDs(OPTION B)
  • All except paracetamol (Piroxicam, Indomethacin, Aspirin, Diclofenac, Celecoxib
 

 2. Severe flare/ Resistant to NSAIDS

 

  • 1-2 joints: Intra-articular corticosteroids (Prednisolone, Triamcinolone)
  • >2 joints: Oral prednisolone

Long-term definitive treatment

 

DMARDs (Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs)

 
  • DOC: Methotrexate (OPTION A)
  • Alternate: Hydroxychloroquine, Sulfasalazine, Infliximab etc. (OPTION D)
  • Action begins after 1 month
  • Not recommended for acute arthritis.
  • Bridge therapy – Start with corticosteroid and maintain the patient on DMARD.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male with a history of gout presents to the clinic with increased frequency of gout attacks. His daily medications include rosuvastatin, low-dose aspirin and losartan for hypertension. He has been advised to avoid certain medications that can exacerbate his gout. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Drugs Associated with Gout

Drugs causing gout

Drugs beneficial in gout

Mnemonic – PAINED

  • P: Pyrazinamide
  • A: Aspirin (Normal dose <2 gms)
  • I: Immunosuppressive: Cyclosporine
  • N: Niacin
  • E: Ethambutol
  • D: Diuretic like loop diuretics, thiazides

Mnemonic – FALSe

  • F: Fenofibrate
  • A: Aspirin in toxic dose >5 gm
  • L: Losartan (OPTION B)
  • Se: Statins (Pravastatin, rosuvastatin) (OPTION D)

Treatment for drug-induced gout: Continue the drug + Allopurinol.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her roommate after intentionally ingesting a large quantity of paracetamol tablets. She reports feeling depressed and wanting to harm herself. On examination, she appears lethargic and complains of right upper quadrant abdominal pain. Laboratory tests reveal elevated liver enzymes. What is the primary pharmacological drug used in the treatment of paracetamol poisoning?
questions.explanation:
Early Stage (12–36 hours post-ingestion)

Later Stage (2–4 days post-ingestion)
  1. Nausea, vomiting & abdominal pain
  2. Liver tenderness
  3. ↑ plasma transaminases
  4. No impairment of consciousness
  1. Right subcostal pain with tender hepatomegaly
  2. Jaundice
  3. Coagulopathy
  4. Renal impairment or failure
  5. Hypoglycemia
  6. Hepatic encephalopathy

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice used in the closure of a PDA in premature infants?
Which of the following is an ionotropic receptor?
questions.explanation:
Receptor type

5-HT1

5-HT2

5-HT3

5-HT4-7

Subtypes

5HT-1A, 5HT-1B, 5HT-1D, 5HT-1E, 5HT-1F, 5HT-1P.

      

Type of receptor

GPCR

GPCR

Ionotropic ligand-gated

GPCR

Mechanism

Inhibit serotonergic activity in the brain, and their agonist drugs are used in migraine prophylaxis and as anxiolytics.

Mediate vascular and visceral smooth muscle contraction, platelet aggregation and neuronal activation in the brain.

Elicit reflex effects like emesis, gut peristalsis, bradycardia, transient hypotension, apnoea, pain, and itch.

Mediate intestinal secretion and augmentation of peristalsis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with a family history of colorectal cancer presents for a screening colonoscopy due to his increased risk. Colonoscopy confirms the presence of multiple adenomatous polyps in the patient's colon. Which drug is prescribed as chemoprevention?
questions.explanation:
Dose

Action

Low dose aspirin
(40-300 mg/day)

Antiplatelet action

Medium dose aspirin

(300-2400 mg/day)

Analgesic and Antipyretic action

High dose aspirin
(2400-4000 mg/day)

Anti-inflammatory action

questions.text: Which prostaglandin analogue is not used to conduct MTP (medical abortion) in the pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
DOC: Misoprostol 400µg, 48 hours after 200 mg of Mifepristone administration.

CLASS

DRUG

ACTION

PGE1 (Option A)

Misoprostol, Gemeprost
 

The uterine contraction expels the abortus.

PGE2 (Option B)

Dinoprostone

PGF2 alpha (Option C)

Carboprost, Dinoprost

Anti-progesterone

Mifepristone

It makes the fetus non-viable.

Anti-metabolite

Methotrexate

It can be used instead of mifepristone.

Not recommended as it has a higher chance of incomplete abortion.

questions.text: In a 35-year-old woman at 40 weeks gestation presenting with an unripe cervix and scheduled for induction, what is the preferred subtype of prostaglandin for cervical ripening in preparation for labour?
questions.explanation:
Prostaglandin

Preparation

Indications

PGE1 (Option B)

Misoprostol

NSAID-induced peptic ulcer

1st trimester MTP abortion

Alprostadil

Erectile dysfunction (cavernosal injection)

Critical limb ischemia

Open ductus arteriosus

Lubiprostone

Irritable bowel syndrome

Gemeprost

1st trimester MTP abortion

PGE2 (Option A)

Dinoprostone

DOC for cervical ripening (Vaginal)

Induction of labour

Medical abortion

PGF2𝛂 (Option C)

Dinoprost

Medical abortion

Carboprost

Resistant postpartum hemorrhage

Medical abortion

Travoprost

Latanoprost

Bimatoprost

Tafluprost

Topical eye drops for treatment of Glaucoma

PGI2 (Option D)

Iloprost

Epoprostenol

Treprostinil

Pulmonary artery hypertension (via inhalation route)

As an antiplatelet during hemodialysis

questions.text: Match the following drugs to their mechanism of action: a) Aspirin i) Inhibits COX 3 b) Meloxicam ii) Inhibits COX 1 and 2 c) Parecoxib iii) Inhibits COX 2 > COX1 d) Paracetamol iv) Inhibits only COX 2
questions.explanation:
a) Aspirin

ii) Inhibits COX 1 and 2

b) Meloxicam

iii) Inhibits COX 2 > COX1

(Preferential COX 2 inhibitors)

c) Parecoxib

iv) Inhibits only COX 2

(Selective COX 2 inhibitors)

d) Paracetamol

i) Inhibits COX 3

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with symptoms of seasonal allergies, including sneezing, rhinorrhea, and itchy eyes. The patient has a history of performing tasks requiring alertness throughout the day. Which antihistamines would be the most suitable choice for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Generation

Drug

Side Effects

Generalised Uses

1st Generation

Diphenhydramine

(Option A)

Sedation, drowsiness, dry mouth, blurred vision

Allergy symptoms, Insomnia, Motion sickness

Chlorpheniramine

Sedation, drowsiness, dry mouth

Allergy symptoms

Hydroxyzine

(Option C)

Anxiety, Allergy symptoms, Pruritus

2nd Generation

Loratadine

(Option D)

Minimal sedation, dry mouth

Allergy symptoms, Urticaria

Cetirizine

Allergy symptoms, Itchiness, Urticaria

Fexofenadine

(Option B)

Non-sedating, minimal side effects

Allergy symptoms, Chronic idiopathic urticaria

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is experiencing severe nausea and vomiting after chemotherapy. Her doctor prescribes a medication to help manage these symptoms. Which of the following medications is most likely to be prescribed?
questions.explanation:
5HT-3 Antagonists (Anti-motility drugs)

5HT-4 Agonists (Prokinetic drugs)

Action
  • Block 5HT-3 receptors in the gastrointestinal tract and central nervous system.
  • Decrease intestinal motility and secretion.
  • Inhibit the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ) in the area postrema, reducing nausea and vomiting.
  • Activate 5HT-4 receptors in the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Increase gastrointestinal motility and secretion.
  • Enhances the release of acetylcholine from enteric neurons.

Drugs
  • Ondansetron (Option A)
  • Granisetron
  • Dolasetron
  • Palonosetron
  • Alosetron
  • Metoclopramide (Option B)
  • Cisapride (withdrawn due to QT prolongation) (Option C)
  • Tegaserod (restricted use due to cardiovascular risks) (Option D)

Uses
  • Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV)
  • Postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV)
  • Radiation-induced nausea and vomiting (RINV)
  • Irritable bowel syndrome with diarrhoea (IBS-D): Alosetron
  • Gastroparesis
  • Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
  • Functional dyspepsia
  • Chronic constipation
  • Postoperative ileus

Adverse Effects

  • Headache
  • Constipation
  • Dizziness
  • Fatigue
  • Prolonged QT interval (rare)
  • Diarrhea
  • Abdominal pain
  • Nausea
  • Headache
  • Prolonged QT interval (Cisapride, Tegaserod)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman has been experiencing frequent and severe migraines. Her doctor recommends a medication that blocks 5HT-2 receptors to help prevent these attacks. Which of the following medications is most likely to be prescribed?
questions.explanation:
Drug

Uses

Cyproheptadine

Migraine prophylaxis, antihistamine

Methysergide

Migraine and cluster headache prophylaxis

Pizotifen

Migraine prophylaxis, antihistamine

Quetiapine (Option C)

Schizophrenia, bipolar disorder

Ketanserin (Option A)

Hypertension, peripheral vascular disease

Ritanserin (Option B)

Investigated for schizophrenia, depression, and sleep disorders

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of migraine without aura, currently on preventive medication, is planning to conceive. She seeks advice on safe medications for treating acute migraine attacks during pregnancy. Which of the following drugs is recommended?
questions.explanation:
Purpose

Drug

Safety in Pregnancy

Comments

First-line (acute)

Acetaminophen

Safe in all trimesters

DOC for acute migraine attack in pregnancy

Step-up (acute)

Codeine

Use with caution

May be added if paracetamol alone is ineffective
 

Caffeine

Safe in moderation

Can be combined with paracetamol for enhanced effect
 

Metoclopramide

Relatively safe, some side effects

Can help with nausea associated with migraine

Rescue (acute)

Sumatriptan

Considered safe based on human data

Most evidence-based triptan; used when first-line fails

Drug

Pregnancy Use

Notes

Acetaminophen

Safe – DOC in pregnancy

Can be used regularly for mild prophylaxis

Propranolol

Used cautiously in 2nd/3rd trimester

Most preferred beta-blocker; used when non-drug measures fail
